articles.headline: Turkey’s Campaign Against Kurdish Militants Takes Toll on Civilians
articles.snippet: Several Turkish cities are under lockdown, hundreds of thousands are displaced, while others are trapped without food or electricity as violent clashes intensify.
articles.abstract: Several Turkish cities are under lockdown, hundreds of thousands are displaced, while others are trapped without food or electricity as violent clashes intensify.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A major Turkish military operation to eradicate Kurdish militants in Turkey’s restive southeast has turned dozens of urban districts into bloody battlefields, displacing hundreds of thousands of civilians and shattering hopes of reviving peace as an old war reaches its deadliest level in two decades.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Says It Will Default on Some Bonds
articles.snippet: The territory’s governor said the island’s total bond default was roughly $174 million million because he had “clawed back” money from a variety of bonds.
articles.abstract: The territory’s governor said the island’s total bond default was roughly $174 million million because he had “clawed back” money from a variety of bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico will default on nearly $174 million in principal and interest payments on bonds on Friday, the first day of 2016, the governor said on Wednesday, increasing the likelihood that the island will face lawsuits from an array of creditors.

articles.headline: Farmers Try Political Force to Twist Open California’s Taps
articles.snippet: Few in agriculture have shaped the debate over water more than the several hundred owners of an arid finger of farmland west of Fresno.
articles.abstract: Few in agriculture have shaped the debate over water more than the several hundred owners of an arid finger of farmland west of Fresno.
articles.lead_paragraph: FIVE POINTS, Calif. — The message that Maria L. Gutierrez gave legislators on Capitol Hill was anguished and blunt: California’s historic drought had not merely left farmland idle. It had destroyed Latino farm workers’ jobs, shuttered Latino businesses and thrown Latino families on the street. Yet Congress had turned a deaf ear to their pleas for more water to revive farming and farm labor.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: In Bill Cosby Case, 3 Pills, Sips of Wine and a Charge of Sexual Assault
articles.snippet: The 2004 case in which he is charged includes many documentary, albeit conflicting, accounts of what took place between Mr. Cosby and Andrea Constand.
articles.abstract: The 2004 case in which he is charged includes many documentary, albeit conflicting, accounts of what took place between Mr. Cosby and Andrea Constand.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was her mentor and one of the most famous people to ever have attended Temple University, where she worked as a director of operations for the women’s basketball program. One night in the winter of 2004 Bill Cosby called Andrea Constand on her cellphone and invited her to his home in Cheltenham, a leafy suburb just north of Philadelphia. The two chatted about her job and career prospects.
articles.byline: By Colin Moynihan and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: It’s Amazon and Also-Rans in Retailers’ Race for Online Sales
articles.snippet: Amazon capped its blockbuster year by reporting what it said was a record-breaking holiday season, shipping 200 million items through its Prime subscription service.
articles.abstract: Amazon capped its blockbuster year by reporting what it said was a record-breaking holiday season, shipping 200 million items through its Prime subscription service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two decades after Jeffrey P. Bezos started Amazon in his Bellevue, Wash., garage, his e-commerce juggernaut could be forgiven for letting up on its rapid growth.
